name: mail_postfix

mail_postfix/db_host.description: The hostname of the postfix configuration MySQL database server

mail_postfix/s3_bucket.description: The namne of the S3 bucket for backups.

mail_postfix/backup_prefix.description: The prefix of the filename stored in S3 for backups.

mail_postfix/db_name.description: The name of the postfix configuration database in MySQL

mail_postfix/backup_history_to_keep.description: The number of S3 backups to keep as history.

aws/secret_access_key.description: This is an Amazon credential. Log in to your AWS account at aws.amazon.com to retrieve your access identifiers. Ex: XVdxPgOM4auGcMlPz61IZGotpr9LzzI07tT8s2Ws

aws/access_key_id.description: This is an Amazon credential. Log in to your AWS account at aws.amazon.com to retrieve you access identifiers. Ex: 1JHQQ4KVEVM02KVEVM02

mail_postfix/db_pass.description: The password to access the postfix configuration database in MySQL

mail_postfix/db_user.description: The username to access the postfix configuration database in MySQL

= EC2 Considerations
Set it up with an EIP, and let Amazon know that you'll be using this as an email relay.

http://aws.amazon.com/contact-us/ec2-email-limit-request/

Make sure your MX record points to an A record, and supply your A record hostname as the reverse lookup when submitting the above form to make sure everything goes smoothly and you don't get blacklisted!

recipes.mail_postfix::s3_backup: Backs up the configuration database to s3
recipes.mail_postfix::enable_continuous_backup: Schedules mail_postfix::s3_backup to be run daily using cron
recipes.mail_postfix::disable_continuous_backup: Stops daily scheduled runs of mail_postfix::s3_backup
recipes.mail_postfix::setup_postfix: Installs postfix with mysql backend configuration
recipes.mail_postfix::s3_restore: Restores the configuration database from s3
